apple_Apple Scab.summary: Apple scab is a fungal disease that causes dark, scabby lesions on leaves, fruit, and twigs. It spreads through spores and thrives in wet conditions.
apple_Apple Scab.cure: Apply fungicides like captan or myclobutanil at bud break and repeat every 10-14 days during wet weather. Prune infected branches and remove fallen leaves.
apple_Apple Scab.prevention: Plant resistant varieties, ensure good air circulation, avoid overhead watering, and clean up fallen leaves and fruit in fall.

apple_Black Rot.summary: Black rot is a fungal disease affecting apples, causing fruit rot, leaf spots, and cankers on branches.
apple_Black Rot.cure: Remove and destroy infected fruit, leaves, and branches. Apply fungicides during bloom and petal fall.
apple_Black Rot.prevention: Prune trees to improve air circulation, avoid wounding trees, and apply dormant sprays in winter.

apple_Cedar Apple Rust.summary: Cedar apple rust is a fungal disease that requires both apple and cedar trees to complete its life cycle, causing orange spots on leaves and fruit.
apple_Cedar Apple Rust.cure: Apply fungicides at green tip and petal fall stages. Remove nearby cedar trees if possible.
apple_Cedar Apple Rust.prevention: Plant rust-resistant apple varieties and maintain distance from cedar trees.

apple_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
apple_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

bellpepper_Bacterial Spot.summary: Bacterial spot causes small, water-soaked spots on leaves, stems, and fruit that turn brown and scabby.
bellpepper_Bacterial Spot.cure: Use copper-based bactericides. Avoid overhead watering and handle plants carefully to prevent spread.
bellpepper_Bacterial Spot.prevention: Rotate crops, use disease-free seeds, and avoid working with wet plants.

bellpepper_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
bellpepper_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

cherry_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
cherry_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

cherry_Powdery Mildew.summary: Powdery mildew appears as white, powdery spots on leaves, stems, and fruit.
cherry_Powdery Mildew.cure: Apply sulfur-based fungicides or neem oil. Improve air circulation by pruning.
cherry_Powdery Mildew.prevention: Avoid overhead watering, plant in sunny locations, and space plants properly.

corn(maize)_Blight.summary: Corn blight causes grayish lesions on leaves that can lead to significant yield loss.
corn(maize)_Blight.cure: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin or propiconazole at tasseling and repeat as needed.
corn(maize)_Blight.prevention: Rotate crops, plant resistant varieties, and avoid overhead irrigation.

corn(maize)_Common Rust.summary: Common rust appears as reddish-brown pustules on leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
corn(maize)_Common Rust.cure: Apply fungicides if infection is severe. Remove and destroy infected leaves.
corn(maize)_Common Rust.prevention: Plant resistant varieties and ensure proper plant spacing for air circulation.

corn(maize)_Gray Leaf Spot.summary: Gray leaf spot causes rectangular lesions on leaves, leading to premature leaf death.
corn(maize)_Gray Leaf Spot.cure: Use fungicides like strobilurins or triazoles. Rotate crops and till under crop residues.
corn(maize)_Gray Leaf Spot.prevention: Plant resistant hybrids and avoid planting corn in the same field consecutively.

corn(maize)_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
corn(maize)_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

grape_Black Measles.summary: Black measles causes dark spots on grape leaves and fruit, affecting quality.
grape_Black Measles.cure: Apply fungicides like mancozeb or copper sulfate. Prune infected parts.
grape_Black Measles.prevention: Ensure good air circulation, avoid overhead watering, and remove fallen leaves.

grape_Black Rot.summary: Black rot affects leaves, stems, and fruit with black lesions and fruit rot.
grape_Black Rot.cure: Use fungicides during bloom and veraison. Remove and destroy infected plant parts.
grape_Black Rot.prevention: Prune for air circulation, avoid wounding vines, and apply dormant sprays.

grape_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
grape_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

peach_Bacterial Spot.summary: Bacterial spot causes small, dark spots on leaves and fruit, leading to defoliation.
peach_Bacterial Spot.cure: Apply copper-based bactericides. Avoid overhead irrigation.
peach_Bacterial Spot.prevention: Plant resistant varieties, prune for air flow, and avoid working with wet plants.

peach_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
peach_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

potato_Early Blight.summary: Early blight causes dark spots with concentric rings on leaves, leading to defoliation.
potato_Early Blight.cure: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil. Remove infected leaves and avoid overhead watering.
potato_Early Blight.prevention: Rotate crops, plant resistant varieties, and mulch to prevent soil splash.

potato_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
potato_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

potato_Late Blight.summary: Late blight causes water-soaked lesions on leaves and tubers, rapidly destroying crops.
potato_Late Blight.cure: Apply fungicides immediately. Remove and destroy infected plants. Use resistant varieties.
potato_Late Blight.prevention: Avoid overhead watering, ensure good drainage, and rotate crops.

strawberry_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
strawberry_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

strawberry_Leaf Scorch.summary: Leaf scorch causes browning of leaf edges, often due to environmental stress or disease.
strawberry_Leaf Scorch.cure: Improve watering practices, ensure proper fertilization. Remove affected leaves.
strawberry_Leaf Scorch.prevention: Plant in well-drained soil, mulch to retain moisture, and avoid drought stress.

tomato_Bacterial Spot.summary: Bacterial spot causes small, dark spots on leaves and fruit with yellow halos.
tomato_Bacterial Spot.cure: Use copper-based bactericides. Avoid overhead watering and handle plants gently.
tomato_Bacterial Spot.prevention: Rotate crops, use disease-free seeds, and avoid wet foliage.

tomato_Early Blight.summary: Early blight causes target-like spots on leaves, leading to defoliation.
tomato_Early Blight.cure: Apply fungicides like copper or chlorothalonil. Remove lower infected leaves.
tomato_Early Blight.prevention: Mulch around plants, water at soil level, and rotate crops.

tomato_Healthy.summary: The plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease.
tomato_Healthy.prevention: Continue good cultural practices like proper watering, fertilization, and pruning.

tomato_Late Blight.summary: Late blight causes dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruit, spreading rapidly.
tomato_Late Blight.cure: Apply fungicides like mancozeb immediately. Remove and destroy infected plants.
tomato_Late Blight.prevention: Ensure good air circulation, avoid overhead watering, and use resistant varieties.

tomato_Leaf Mold.summary: Leaf mold causes yellow spots on upper leaves and mold on lower surfaces.
tomato_Leaf Mold.cure: Improve ventilation, reduce humidity. Apply fungicides if necessary.
tomato_Leaf Mold.prevention: Space plants properly, avoid overhead watering, and prune for air flow.

tomato_Septoria Leaf Spot.summary: Septoria leaf spot causes small, circular spots with dark borders on leaves.
tomato_Septoria Leaf Spot.cure: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil. Remove infected leaves.
tomato_Septoria Leaf Spot.prevention: Rotate crops, avoid overhead watering, and mulch to prevent soil splash.

tomato_Spider Mites.summary: Spider mites cause stippling and webbing on leaves, weakening plants.
tomato_Spider Mites.cure: Use insecticidal soap or neem oil. Increase humidity and wash plants.
tomato_Spider Mites.prevention: Keep plants well-watered, avoid dusty conditions, and introduce beneficial insects.

tomato_Target Spot.summary: Target spot causes concentric ring lesions on leaves and fruit.
tomato_Target Spot.cure: Apply fungicides. Remove infected plant parts.
tomato_Target Spot.prevention: Improve air circulation, avoid wet foliage, and rotate crops.

tomato_Tomato Mosaic Virus.summary: TMV causes mottled leaves, stunted growth, and distorted fruit.
tomato_Tomato Mosaic Virus.cure: Remove and destroy infected plants. No chemical cure available.
tomato_Tomato Mosaic Virus.prevention: Use virus-free seeds, disinfect tools, and control aphids that spread the virus.

tomato_Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.summary: TYLCV causes yellowing and curling of leaves, stunted growth.
tomato_Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.cure: Remove infected plants. Use insecticides to control whiteflies.
tomato_Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.prevention: Use resistant varieties, control whitefly vectors, and avoid planting near infected areas.
